newsitem.title: BELGIUM: Bulgaria seeks special deal with NATO.
newsitem.headline: Bulgaria seeks special deal with NATO.

text.p: Bulgaria's Foreign Affairs Minister Stoyan Stalev called on Friday for a special status for former communist countries which fail to win NATO membership at the first attempt.

Declining to accept his country would not gain alliance membership "in the first wave", Stalev said countries left outside should be accorded a special status differentiating them from partnership nations not seeking full membership.

"There has to be a special procedure for countries that will not be invited in first time round," he told reporters after meeting the 16 alliance ambassadors at the North Atlantic Treaty Organisation's (NATO's) Brussels headquarters.

NATO sources said Sofia was looking for regular "16+1" meetings and other regular bilateral contacts in addition to those offered to some 27 Partnership for Peace (PFP) many of which do not want alliance membership.

NATO countries are to invite certain countries to join the alliance at a special summit in Madrid next July. A total of 12 countries want to join, but only three -- Poland, Hungary and the Czech Republic -- are expected to be successful.
Stalev told the ambassadors his country wanted to be considered as a serious applicant for inclusion in the first wave and jointly with Romania.
"The south-east region of Europe is very important for wider European stability," he said.
Bulgaria's reformist coalition which was reelected in polls last weekend has reversed the policy of the previous government and made NATO membership its top foreign policy goal.
